data.value: Values of the integrand at each of the

points of a QMC sample are used to produce an estimate of the integral. This estimate is drawn from a population of possible estimates of the integral, the value of which we obtain depends on the particular points at which the integral was evaluated. We perform this process
times, each time evaluating the integrand at different scrambled QMC points, effectively drawing i.i.d. random samples from the population of integral estimates. The sample mean
of these integral estimates is an unbiased estimator of the true value of the integral, and the standard error of the mean
of these estimates may be used to generate confidence intervals using the t distribution with
degrees of freedom. Perhaps counter-intuitively, increasing
while keeping the total number of function evaluation points
fixed tends to reduce the actual error, whereas increasing
tends to decrease the error estimate.
The integrand. Must accept a single arguments
, an array which specifies the point at which to evaluate the integrand. For efficiency, the function should be vectorized to compute the integrand for each element an array of shape
One-dimensional arrays specifying the lower and upper integration limits, respectively, of each of the
(default: 8) statistically independent estimates of the integral will be produced. The total number of points at which the integrand
An instance of the QMCEngine from which to sample QMC points. The QMCEngine must be initialized to a number of dimensions corresponding with the number of variables
. The provided QMCEngine is used to produce the first integral estimate. If
is greater than one, additional QMCEngines are spawned from the first (with scrambling enabled, if it is an option.) If a QMCEngine is not provided, the default
will be initialized with the number of dimensions determine from
returns the log of the integrand, and the result object contains the log of the integral.
The error estimate. See Notes for interpretation.
Compute an integral in N-dimensions using Quasi-Monte Carlo quadrature.
QMC quadrature is particularly useful for computing integrals in higher dimensions. An example integrand is the probability density function of a multivariate normal distribution.
To compute the integral over the unit hypercube:
A two-sided, 99% confidence interval for the integral may be estimated as:

signature.value: _qmc_quad(func, a, b, *, n_points=1024, n_estimates=8, qrng=None, log=False, args=None)
